Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Otolemur nutrition, behavior, and microbiome dynamics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this RAPID project, the investigators will collect baseline nutritional, behavioral, biomarker, and microbiome data on a provisioned group of small-bodied, nocturnal primates (galagos). The research will advance fundamental knowledge about primate adaptations and ecology. The project will inform primate conservation efforts and will provide unique opportunities for student training and mentoring in primate research at an EPSCoR state institution, including for students from groups that are underrepresented in STEM fields.

The investigators will establish a research program to examine diet, nutrition, behavior and microbiome for Otolemur garnettii (n=14, ages 3-23 years). Research aims will focus on the impact of dietary alteration on digestibility of nutrients (including protein and fiber); relationships between food choice, stress hormones and behaviors; and relationships between gut and oral microbiome, nutrition and welfare; and age-related aspects of well-being and nutrition. The project will also be able to test hypotheses about changes in behavior, well-being, and microbiome with a shift to naturalistic diet and housing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major goals of the project were to determine hormonal, behavioral, and biological impacts of dietary changes in captive housed Otolemur garnettii. This included feeding the animals diets that are similar to those that are seen in the wild (one frugivorous diet and one insectivorous diet). We were able to determine that alteration of the diet in Otolemur garnettii impacted both behavioral and biological (digestibility and microbiome) factors, and that individual food choice is a major determining factor in success of a diet and its potential impacts. 

We were able to successfully implement baseline, frugivorous, and insectivorous diets to the colony. Our goals were to better understand the dietary patterns of this species, as they are not well understood in the wild. Moreover, we were interested in finding if altering this diet impacted behavior, microbiome, and digestibility. We found that there is a great deal of individual difference in food preferences, and while some individuals preferred the insectivorous or baseline diets, the majority preferred the frugivorous diet. We also found that dependent on the diet fed, greatly influenced not only digestibility of diet, but also of the microbiome. We found that in Otolemur garnettii, diet and the individual dietary preferences has an effect on the gut microbiome. Moreover, the length of time that an individual ingests a particular diet shows predictive trends for which microbes will be more present. 

From the results of this study, we are confident that there are many more avenues to explore in not only the particular behavior and biology of Otolemur garnettii, but more importantly the importance and efficacy of using captive housed individuals in better understanding their wild counterparts, particularly of those that are notoriously difficult to work with in the wild.
